Literature Review: Animal communication in linguistic and cognitive perspective has garnered significant attention in recent years, with numerous studies revealing striking similarities between the two. This literature review aims to provide an in-depth analysis of the comparative studies on analogy and homology in animal communication, and their implications for linguistic and cognitive perspectives. We will examine the combinatorial features of animal communication, and how they relate to natural language, as well as the cognitive capacities of attention manipulation that underlie these similarities. Our review will also introduce a new, graded taxonomy of means of attention manipulation, including the novel class of Ladyginian, which is distinct from the more familiar Gricean interaction. By exploring the boundaries between analogy and homology, we hope to shed new light on the complex relationships between animal communication and human language.
